1.title: Unknown Lady
1.sitter_text: Unknown Lady (perhaps of the Vavasour family)
1.description_content: Isaac Oliver's portrait of a fashionably attired unknown lady depicts a young, stylishly attired woman, with a black hat and a profusion of white lace and pearls. She has long been considered a ‘typical’ example of this artist's work.
1.description_physical:
The ultraviolet (UV) image of this work shows that numerous areas have been retouched. These include portions of her hat and black costume, which display a greenish fluorescence under UV illumination, indicative of the presence of modern pigments, such as zinc white (as confirmed by additional X-ray fluorescence [XRF] analysis). Extensive repainting can also be identified throughout the white passages of the costume.

The white overpainting appears to be covering dull grey (original) paint, whose muted colour must have been the reason for the extensive intervention. This grey pigment has been identified as calomel, which was probably white initially, but exposure to light or possibly alkali turned it grey, thus making necessary the extensive repainting.
1.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, lead white, vermilion (retouch: bone black, zinc white, indigo); lace: calomel (retouch: barium sulphate); ruff: (retouch: barium sulphate, calcium-based compound)
1.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Skin: lead white, vermilion, red lead; lips: red lead, vermilion, pink lake
1.pigments_hair_and_beard: Carbon-based black, red lead, lead white, yellow earth pigments

49.title: A lady (b. c. 1567)
49.description_content: This miniature is one of the earliest known attributable to Isaac Oliver.
49.description_physical:
Inscription in gold, 'Anno Domini 1587, aetatis suae 20'
UV image: retouching evident on the flesh tone, white shirt and ruff, appearing of greenish colour under UV light and associated with the use of zinc white.  
The palette identified is consistent with the materials employed by Isaac Oliver.
49.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, lead white; ruff: lead white (retouch: zinc white); pink ribbon: lead white, pink lake
49.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Skin: lead white, red lead (retouch: zinc white); lips: red lake
49.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, lead white, carbon black
49.pigments_jewellery: Gold (yellow layer underneath: lead tin yellow type I)

56.title: Jane Boughton, née Coningsby (b. 1553)
56.description_physical:
The palette identified is compatible with the materials available to Hilliard.
UV image: the flesh tone appears bright white, due to the fluorescence of the parchment underneath; the orange UV fluorescence colour is associated to the use of lead white. 
The verso of the playing card was analysed: red areas: vermilion; dark and blue areas: indigo; green area: indigo and likely a yellow dye; yellow areas: yellow dye(?); purple areas: red/ purple dye(?)
56.pigments_costume: White shirt and ruff: lead white; black bodice: bone black; headdress: earth pigments, bone black, lead-based pigments
56.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Skin: lead white, chalk, vermilion, red lead(?); lips: pink lake, red lead(?)
56.pigments_hair_and_beard: Hair: earth pigment, chalk, lead tin yellow, carbon black
56.pigments_jewellery: Silver; gold (orange underlayer: earth pigments and arsenic sulphides)

57.title: Unknown Woman, formerly called Anne, Lady Hunsdon (c. 1529–1607)
57.sitter_text: Unknown Woman, formerly called Anne, Lady Hunsdon (c. 1529–1607)
57.description_physical:
The UV image shows that the miniature is in a good state of preservation. The pale orange UV fluorescence colour (for instance evident on the ruff) is due to the presence of lead white.

Silver has been detected in the pupils, presumably used to indicate a reflection of light. 
 
The playing card was not accessible for the analysis, but the mercury (Hg) MA-XRF map shows the presence of one heart, likely made of vermilion.
57.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, lead white, zinc white (retouching); blue gem: ultramarine blue; red enamelled figures: red lead; white ruff: lead white, carbon black (shading), barium sulphate (retouching)
57.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Skin: lead white, carbon black, red lead(?). Lips: vermilion, lead white
57.pigments_hair_and_beard: Yellow earth pigment, lead tin yellow, lead white(?), carbon black
57.pigments_jewellery: Gold (yellow underlayer: lead tin yellow type I, lead white, arsenic sulphides); silver

58.title: Unknown Man, formerly called Edward, Baron Herbert of Cherbury
58.sitter_text: Unknown Man, formerly called Edward, Baron Herbert of Cherbury
58.description_physical:
UV and NIR images show retouched areas on the background, which appear light blue and light grey, respectively. 
The monogram is painted on a retouched area, but the gold (Au) MA-XRF map shows the presence of a monogram (likely original) previously painted underneath.

The pigment palette is consistent with Oliver’s materials and technique, especially regarding the mixtures for the flesh tones and hair. Lips contain vermilion, which is usually not identified after 1610.
The yellow lace is unusual, however not in itself an argument against an attribution to Oliver. It is however notable, on comparison, that the quality (in terms of the consistency and precision of the paint handling) of the execution of the lace in AGOID.29377 is less accomplished than other examples more securely attributed to Oliver.
58.pigments_background: Azurite (retouched with zinc white, cobalt blue, cerulean blue)
58.pigments_costume: Black doublet: bone black, lead white; ruff: lead white and carbon black (grey lower layer), lead white (lace), lead tin yellow (yellow lace)
58.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Skin: lead white, chalk, red lead(?); lips: vermilion, red lead(?), red lake
58.pigments_hair_and_beard: Yellow earth pigments, lead white, lead tin yellow, carbon black(?)

62.title: Portrait of a Gentleman
62.description_physical:
The miniature is in a good state of conservation. 
The UV image shows an orange UV colour on the flesh tone, suggesting the use of lead white. 

The lead (Pb) and calcium (Ca) MA-XRF maps show a possible change in the shape of the hat.
Calcium, likely as chalk, is used to paint the base layer of the ruff, whereas the lace is painted with lead white, and is also used to modulate the bone black of the doublet.
62.pigments_costume: Black doublet: bone black, lead white; ruff: chalk, lead white (lace)
62.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Skin: lead white, red lead, earth pigments; lips: red lead

images_micrographs.description: ruff, proper right side, raking light

62.Credit: The Thomson Collection at the Art Gallery of Ontario

63.title: Portrait of William Drummond of Hawthornden (c. 1615)
63.description_physical:
The UV image shows limited retouching on the white ruff and flesh areas: the retouching appears bright yellow in UV which is usually associated with the presence of zinc white. The dull orange UV fluorescence colour evident on the ruff is instead due to the use of lead white, and is original. A dark red/maroon UV fluorescence colour on the background is likely due to the use of a red lake and indigo.

The x-ray image highlights the wood grain of the support onto which the miniature is laid. 
This image is also particularly useful in this case because it reveals the presence of an upside-down heart  in the area of the sitter's face. This symbol is present on the playing card, the back of which remains inaccessible due to the framing of this object. The MA-XRF analysis suggests that this heart was executed using vermilion.
63.pigments_costume: Doublet: bone black, lead white. White ruff: lead white (zinc white for retouching)
63.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Skin: lead white, chalk, red lead?, earth pigment?. Lips: red lake, red lead?
63.pigments_hair_and_beard: earth pigments, chalk, lead-based pigment, carbon black?
63.Credit: The Thomson Collection at the Art Gallery of Ontario

64.title: Portrait of Henry Stewart, Lord Darnley, second consort of Mary, Queen of Scots
64.sitter_text: Portrait of Henry Stewart, Lord Darnley, second consort of Mary, Queen of Scots
64.description_physical:
The miniature is in a good state of preservation. The UV image shows the presence of some losses in the pictorial film, which result in bright white areas corresponding to the parchment underneath. The two small areas on the flesh tone with a bright fluorescence are caused by a retouching made with zinc white. 

The mercury (Hg) map shows considerable amount of vermilion used for outlining facial features and in the lips and hair.
The barium (Ba) in the background is likely to be an impurity of azurite.
64.pigments_costume: Doublet: lead tin yellow type I, red earth
64.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Skin: lead white, chalk, vermilion; lips: vermilion
64.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, chalk, lead tin yellow, lead white, vermilion, red lead(?), carbon black

background, proper left side, raking light

64.Credit: The Thomson Collection at the Art Gallery of Ontario

71.title: Portrait of a young woman, called Mrs Cam of Newport, Gloucestershire
71.description_physical: UV image: a loss of colour is evident in the lower part of the miniature, which appears bright white under UV light, possibly due to the fluorescence of the parchment support. An orange UV colour is instead typical of lead white, and used for the dress. Other retouched areas are evident on the background, at the top and right side. The calcium and lead MA-XRF maps show a possible change in the length of the hair.
71.pigments_costume: Dress: lead white dress; white veil: lead white, azurite; red flowers: red lead, red lake; blue stems: indigo; green stems: copper-based pigment, yellow dye; green leaves: indigo, brochantite
71.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Skin: lead white, vermilion(?), red lead(?); lips: vermilion, red lake
71.pigments_hair_and_beard: Hair: earth and umber pigments, lead-based pigment, carbon black, lead tin yellow, copper-based pigment
71.pigments_jewellery: Silver jewels (red underlayer: earth pigments, red lead); gold jewels (red underlayer: earth pigments, red lead)
